stocks.note: *Numbers as of market close on Feb 10th
stocks.news:
Datadog's New Tricks:

Datadog (DDOG +13.74%) was the top dog in the S&P 500 yesterday, rising over 15% at one point.

Why? It beat Q4 2025 expectations, and its revenue was up 29%.

Datadog sells monitoring and analytics to AI companies like Amazon (AMZN -0.87%) and OpenAI.

Flashback: Datadog stock had fallen 16% during the "SaaSpocalypse", and is still slightly down YTD.

(A)I Don't Need You:

Financial services stocks fell on Tuesday because an AI software that can pretty much do the same thing was launched.

A Bloomberg analyst says AI could reduce the need for traditional, in-person financial services.

Charles Schwab (SCHW -7.42%), Raymond James (RJF -8.75%), and LPL (LPLA -8.31%) all dropped over 8% at one point on the news.

BP Hits Pause:

British oil giant BP (BP -5.75%) said it will take a break from stock buybacks.

economy.commentary:
December To Forget:

Lexus might run a "December to Remember" sales event every year.

But last year was a December to Forget for retailers.

Retail sales numbers came in flat for the month, below expectations.

So what? Consumers pulled back their spending, which can be a warning sign for the overall economy.

The AI Paradox:

AI has been promised to make life easier and eventually even replace some workers.

But a new study from Harvard shows that so far, the opposite is happening: AI is making work more intense.

That's because instead of reducing workload, employees are now just adding more tasks because AI allows them to do more.

crypto.note: *Numbers as of 4:15 pm ET on Feb 10th
crypto.commentary:
Coinbase Falls:

Coinbase (COIN -2.83%) shares fell after JPMorgan (JPM -1.19%) cut its price target by 27%.

The bank says crypto conditions aren't great right now: prices have fallen, and regulations are still not solidified.

Coinbase has also had bigger price swings than Bitcoin itself, and is down nearly 50% in the last 6 months.

real_estate.homebuilder:
Here For A Long Time:

Recently, homeowners in the U.S. have said we're here for a long time, not a good time.

‚Ä¢ The average person selling his/her house has lived in it for more than 8 years‚Ä¶ double the average of around 4 years in 2000.

That means families are staying put for longer, leading to fewer overall sales in the real estate market.
real_estate.commentary:
üìä California Statewide Update (Released Yesterday, Feb 10):

If you are keeping an eye on the macro trends, the California Association of Realtors (C.A.R.) released their Q4 2025 affordability report yesterday. It brought a sliver of good news: housing affordability in California saw a slight improvement compared to both last quarter and last year, driven by a dip in borrowing costs. However, it's still tight‚Äîa household still needs a minimum annual income of roughly $213,200 to qualify for a median-priced California home ($869,300).

üè° Alameda County: Spring Buyers Are Waking Up Early:

Across the board, the market is waking up ahead of the traditional spring rush.

‚Ä¢ Buyers Rushing Rates: Local real estate reports published earlier this week highlight that buyers who sat on the sidelines in late 2025 are cautiously re-entering the market to lock in current mortgage rates (currently hovering around 6.35%) before they potentially rise later in the year.

‚Ä¢ Pricing & Inventory: The median sale price in Alameda County is hovering around $950,000 to $968,000. Inventory remains tight‚Äîdown about 8% year-over-year‚Äîmeaning move-in-ready homes and condos in places like Oakland, Hayward, and Alameda are seeing a lot of foot traffic and quick sales.

‚Ä¢ Major AI Tech Win for Local Business: Fremont-headquartered semiconductor company Aehr Test Systems made major headlines today. They announced a massive strategic win, securing an initial production purchase order from a lead hyperscale customer. They will be providing their ultra-high-power "Sonoma" testing systems for next-generation AI processors, a great win for Fremont's local tech footprint.
